notes: American supercar with massive V10 engine. No traction control or ABS initially. GTS coupe added 1996. Hand-built at New Mack Assembly. Exotic performance requires specialized service expertise. Data sourced from Wikipedia Dodge Viper article, January 2025 revision.

Full-size sedan on LH platform (cab-forward design). Shared with Chrysler Concorde/LHS and Eagle Vision. Aerodynamic styling. Popular rental fleet vehicle. Data sourced from Wikipedia Dodge Intrepid article, January 2025 revision.

Compact car replacing Shadow/Sundance. Fun, affordable transportation. Available as sedan or coupe. Dual airbags standard. Popular with young buyers. Data sourced from Wikipedia Dodge Neon article, January 2025 revision.

Mid-size sedan on JA platform (Cloud Cars). Replaced Spirit. Available as sedan or coupe. Competed with Honda Accord and Toyota Camry. Data sourced from Wikipedia Dodge Stratus article, January 2025 revision.

Sports coupe on JA platform. Shared with Chrysler Sebring coupe. Built by Mitsubishi in Illinois (Diamond-Star Motors). Replaced Daytona. Data sourced from Wikipedia Dodge Avenger article, January 2025 revision.

Second-generation mid-size pickup. First Dakota with V8 engine option. Club Cab configuration added. Available in 2WD or 4WD. Competed with Ford Ranger and Chevrolet S-10. Data sourced from Wikipedia Dodge Dakota article, January 2025 revision.

Full-size SUV based on Dakota platform. Three-row seating for 8. Body-on-frame construction. Competed with Ford Explorer and Chevrolet Blazer. Data sourced from Wikipedia Dodge Durango article, January 2025 revision.

Third-generation Caravan on AS platform. Grand Caravan long-wheelbase variant. Optional all-wheel drive (1991-1992). Driver-side sliding door added 1994. Data sourced from Wikipedia Dodge Caravan article, January 2025 revision.
